{{EngvarB|date=February 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2015}} {{Infobox Hindu leader |name = Gauḍapāda |image = Shri Gaudapadacharya Statue.jpg |caption = Adi Guru Shri Gauḍapādāchārya |birth_date = |birth_place= |birth_name = |death_date = |death_place= |known = |religion = [[Hinduism]] |founder = [[Shri Gaudapadacharya Math]] |philosophy = [[Advaita Vedanta]] |honors = |footnotes = }} {{Advaita}} {{Hindu philosophy}} '''Gauḍapāda''' (c.6th century CE),{{sfn|Raju|1971|p=177}} also referred as '''{{IAST|Gauḍapādācārya}}''',{{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=103}} was an early medieval era [[Hindu]] philosopher and scholar of the [[Vedanta]] school of [[Hindu philosophy]].{{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=105}}TRV Murti (1955), The central philosophy of Buddhism, Routledge (2008 Reprint), {{ISBN|978-0-415-46118-4}}, page 114 While details of his biography are uncertain, his ideas inspired others such as [[Adi Shankara]] who called him a ''Paramaguru'' (highest teacher).{{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=103}}{{Sfn|Sarma|2007|pp=125-126}} Gaudapada was the author or compiler of the ''{{IAST|Māṇḍukya Kārikā}}'', also known as ''Gaudapada Karika''.{{sfn|Nakamura|2004|p=308}} The text consists of four chapters (also called four books{{Sfn|Potter|1981|pp=106-111}}), of which Chapter Four uses Buddhist terminology thereby showing it was influenced by Buddhism. However, doctrinally Gaudapada's work is Vedantin, and not Buddhist.{{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=105}}{{sfn|Nakamura|2004|p=311}} The first three chapters of Gaudapada's text have been influential in the [[Advaita Vedanta]] tradition. Parts of the first chapter that include the ''[[Mandukya Upanishad]]'' have been considered a valid scriptural source by the [[Dvaita]] and [[Vishistadvaita]] schools of Vedanta,{{sfn|Nakamura|2004|p=280}} but nothing from chapter four with Buddhist flavor has found acceptance or use in the Vedanta school of Hinduism. ==Dates== The century in which Gaudapada lived and his life details are uncertain. Estimates vary from early 6th{{sfn|Michael Comans|2000|p=163}}{{sfn|Raju|1971|p=177}} to 7th century CE.{{sfn|Nakamura|2004|p=3}} He is generally dated from estimates for [[Adi Shankara]], whose teacher [[Govinda Bhagavatpada]] is presumed to be the direct disciple of Gaudapada. Shankara in some texts, refers to Gaudapada as the "teacher's teacher" who knows the tradition of the Vedānta (sampradāya-vit). Assuming how long each lived and when, Gaudapada is estimated to have lived sometime in the 7th century CE.{{sfn|Potter|1981|p=103}} Alternatively, states Potter, the phrase "teacher's teacher" should not be taken literally, and more in the sense of another phrase he uses for Gaudapada, namely ''Paramaguru'' (highest teacher).{{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=103}} He may have been the guru of Sankara's teacher, but was likely a more distant guru, states Michael Comans (aka [[Vasudevacharya]]).{{Sfn|Michael Comans|2000|p=2, 163}} Another estimate places him around the early 6th century.[http://www.iep.utm.edu/gauḍapad/ Gaudapada], Devanathan Jagannathan, University of Toronto, IEP{{Sfn|Sarma|2007|pp=125-126}} This estimate is based on Buddhist literature, and particularly those of scholars Bhavaviveka, Santaraksita and Kamalasila who cite ''Gauḍapada kārikās''.{{Sfn|Michael Comans|2000|pp=45-46}} Bhavaviveka was a contemporary of [[Dharmapala of Nalanda|Dharmapala]], states Karl Potter, while Chinese texts and travel accounts place Dharmapala in the mid 6th century CE. Assuming the Buddhist and Chinese records are reliable, and for Bhavaviveka to have quoted ''Gauḍapada kārikās'', Gaudapada must have lived around 500 CE, or sometime in the first half of 6th century CE. But, it is certain that Gaudapada lived after the 4th century because he cites some Buddhist views of Nāgārjuna and [[Asanga]], the latter of whom various accounts place in 4th century India. ==Mandukya Karika== [[File:Gaudapada Mandukya Karika manuscript page sample i, Sanskrit, Devanagari script.jpg|thumb|left|The Mandukya Karika is an influential Vedanta text. Above: a manuscript page (Sanskrit, Devanagari script)]] ===Authorship=== Gaudapada wrote or compiled{{sfn|Nakamura|2004|p=308}} the ''{{IAST|Māṇḍukya Kārikā}}'', also known as the ''{{IAST|Gauḍapāda Kārikā}}'' and as the ''{{IAST|Āgama Śāstra}}''.{{refn|group=note|Nakamura notes that there are contradictions in doctrine between the four chapters.{{sfn|Nakamura|2004|p=308}}}} Some scholars, states Karl Potter, doubt that ''Gaudapada Karika'' was written by one author.{{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=103}} The ''{{IAST|Māṇḍukya Kārikā}}'' is a concise explanation, in verse form,{{refn|group=note|Karika is defined by Monier-Williams as "concise statement in verse of (esp. philosophy and grammar) doctrines" in the Indian traditions.Monier Williams (1899), Sanskrit-English Dictionary, 2nd Ed, Oxford University Press, कारिका}} of the doctrines in ''[[Mandukya Upanishad]]'', one of the shortest but a profound [[Upanishad]], consisting of just 12 sentences.{{Sfn|Sarma|2007|p=126}} Even before the time of Adi Shankara, Mandukya Upanishad was considered to be a [[Śruti]], but not one particularly important during his era.{{sfn|Nakamura|2004|p=280}} In later periods it acquired a higher value, and expressing the Upanishadic essence. {{sfn|Nakamura|2004|p=280}} The Karika, notably, presents rational arguments from dream states, infinitude and finitude, space and time, causality, disintegration, and generation in support of the advaita doctrine.See Introduction of ''Mandukya Upanishad with the Karika of Gaudapada and the Commentary of Shankaracharya'' (trans.Swami Gambhirananda. Calcutta: Advaita Ashrama, 1995) and Domenic Marbaniang, "The Advaitin Search for Unity in Diversity", ''Epistemics of Divine Reality: An Argument for Rational Fideism'', PhD Dissertation (Bangalore: ACTS Academy of Higher Education, 2007). The ''{{IAST|Māṇḍukya Kārikā}}'' is the earliest extant systematic treatise on {{IAST|Advaita Vedānta}},Sharma, C. (1997). ''A Critical Survey of Indian Philosophy'', Delhi: Motilal Banarsidass, {{ISBN|81-208-0365-5}}, p. 239 though it is not the oldest work to present Advaita views,{{sfn|Nakamura|2004|p=211}} nor the only pre-Sankara work with the same type of teachings.{{sfn|Nakamura|2004|p=211}} According to Hajime Nakamura, not only was the ''Gaudapada Karika'' treasured in the Advaita tradition, the text was revered and highly respected in [[Vishistadvaita]] and [[Dvaita]] Vedanta schools of Hinduism as well.{{sfn|Nakamura|2004|p=280}} Gaudapada's text, adds Nakamura, was treasured but not considered a Sruti by Advaita scholars, while [[Ramanuja]] and [[Madhvacharya]] of non-Advaita schools considered its first chapter to be a Sruti.{{sfn|Nakamura|2004|p=280}} ===Contents=== The Gaudapadiya Karika has 215 [[Sanskrit prosody|metered verses]] which are divided into four chapters: # Chapter One (29 verses) — [[Āgama (Hinduism)|Agama, or Agama Prakarana]] (Traditional doctrine, includes 12 verses of the Mandukya Upanishad){{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=106}}{{Sfn|Sarma|2007|p=126}} # Chapter Two (38 verses) — Vaitathya Prakarana (Unreality){{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=107}} # Chapter Three (48 verses) — Adavaita Prakarana (Nonduality){{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=108}} # Chapter Four (100 verses) — Alatasanti Prakarana (The Peace of the Firebrand){{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=110}} Chronologically, according to [[Hajime Nakamura]], the Buddhist texts that quote from ''Gaudapada Karikas'' imply that the Vedantic ideas in the first three chapters are of greater antiquity. Most of Chapter Three of the compilation of ''Gaudapada Karika'' was complete by 400–500 CE, states Nakamura.{{sfn|Nakamura|2004|p=309}} He estimates that most of Chapter One was complete by 300–400 CE, while Chapter Two which presupposes Chapter One can be dated to have been mostly complete after Chapter One but before Chapter Three.{{sfn|Nakamura|2004|p=310}} Most of the Chapter Four was written sometime between 400 and 600 CE.{{sfn|Nakamura|2004|p=309}} ====Chapter One: Traditional Doctrine (Agama)==== {{Quote box |quote = '''Om is bliss''' [[Om]] is [[Brahman]], both the higher and lower, as well as [[Ishvara]] residing in the hearts of everyone, it is both without measure and of unlimited measure, the cessation of duality, it is bliss. |source = —''Gaudapada Karika 1.28–29''
Translator: Karl Potter{{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=106}}For Sanskrit original and an alternate translation: RD Karmarkar (1953), [https://archive.org/stream/Gaudapada-Karika.English/Gaudapada-Karika#page/n67/mode/2up Gaudapada Karika], Bhandarkar Oriental Research Institute, Poona, pages 9 with footnotes, 66-67 |bgcolor=#FFE0BB |align = right }} The [[Ātman (Hinduism)|Self]] resides in one's body in three forms: waking state, sleeping dreamy state and in deep sleep state, according to Potter's translation. When awake, the Self experiences the [[Vishva]] – the external objects and the visible; when dreaming, it experiences the [[Taijasa]] – the internal mind objects and what appears in the dreams; when in deep sleep, the Self experiences [[Prajñā (Hinduism)|Prajna]] – the unpolarized, the fruits of the heart and bliss.{{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=106}} The description of these states of self are similar, states Arvind Sharma, to those found in [[Brihadaranyaka Upanishad]] and other ancient Hindu texts.{{cite book|author=Arvind Sharma|title=Sleep as a State of Consciousness in Advaita Vedanta|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qVc5Deglvb8C |year=2012| publisher=State University of New York Press|isbn=978-0-7914-8430-2|pages=43–45}} Gaudapada presents the competing traditional theories about life in vogue, before and in his times, in Karika 6 through 9. Some claim creation is the result of the expansion of the Self, some claim it is a mere magic show, some claim the creation is from God's desire, some claim ''Kala'' (time) creates all beings.{{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=106}} In Karika 10, the text states there is a fourth state of the Self, called Turiya, one of ''Advaita'' (nonduality), all pervading, unchanging and without ''Dukkha'' (sorrow).{{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=106}}{{cite book|author=Arvind Sharma|title=Sleep as a State of Consciousness in Advaita Vedanta|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qVc5Deglvb8C |year=2012| publisher=State University of New York Press|isbn=978-0-7914-8430-2|pages=41–48}} This fourth state of Self in ''Gaudapada Karika'' is found in chapters 8.7 through 8.12 of [[Chandogya Upanishad]], which discusses the "four states of consciousness" as awake, dream-filled sleep, deep sleep, and beyond deep sleep.PT Raju (1985), Structural Depths of Indian Thought, State University New York Press, {{ISBN|978-0887061394}}, pages 32-33; '''Quote''': "We can see that this story [in Chandogya Upanishad] is an anticipation of the Mandukya doctrine, (...)"Robert Hume, [https://archive.org/stream/thirteenprincipa028442mbp#page/n289/mode/2up Chandogya Upanishad - Eighth Prathapaka, Seventh through Twelfth Khanda], Oxford University Press, pages 268-273 The ''Vishva'' and ''Taijasa'' state of Self – states Gaudapada – can be a source of cause and effect, the ''Prajna'' is only cause, while ''Turiya'' state is neither.{{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=106}} It is the waking state and dream state that lead to awareness, errors and unawareness. The perceived duality of the world is [[Maya (illusion)|Maya]], when in reality there is only nonduality.{{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=106}} Chapter One ends with the discussion of the [[Om]] and its symbolism for Brahman, and the Atman within the heart of all living beings.{{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=106}}{{Sfn|Isaeva|1995|p=30-34}} ====Chapter Two: Unreality (Vaitathya)==== Unreal are the dream objects during sleep, states Gaudapada, because the one who dreams never actually goes to place he dreams of, and because whatever situation he dreams about is something he leaves upon waking up. This is in the scripture [[Brihadaranyaka Upanishad]].{{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=107}} In the same sense, the true reality is covered up for man even in his waking state, state Karikas 4-6 of Chapter Two, because, translates Potter, "any object nonexistent in the beginning and in the end is also nonexistent in the middle".{{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=107}}For Sanskrit original and translation: RD Karmarkar (1953), [https://archive.org/stream/Gaudapada-Karika.English/Gaudapada-Karika#page/n67/mode/2up Gaudapada Karika], Bhandarkar Oriental Research Institute, Poona, page 10-11 with footnotes When we sleep, we feel the external things we dream about are real and the internal states as unreal, but in the awakened state we realize both are unreal. In the same way, in our waking state whatever we apprehend to be real and unreal are both unreal, covering up the true reality, state Karikas 10-15.{{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=107}} But this assertion leads to the obvious question, states Gaudapada, that if both internal and external are not true reality, who is it that imagines, who apprehends them and who cognizes?{{Sfn|Isaeva|1995|p=43}} Gaudapada submits his answer as the Atman (Self, soul).{{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=107}}{{Sfn|Isaeva|1995|p=43}}For Sanskrit original and translation: RD Karmarkar (1953), [https://archive.org/stream/Gaudapada-Karika.English/Gaudapada-Karika#page/n69/mode/2up Gaudapada Karika], Bhandarkar Oriental Research Institute, Poona, page 12 with footnotes 11-12; Quote:
उभयोरपि वैतथ्यं भेदानां स्थानयोर्यदि ।
क एतान्बुध्यते भेदान्को वै तेषां विकल्पकः ॥ ११ ॥
कल्पयत्यात्मनाऽऽत्मानमात्मा देवः स्वमायया |
स एव बुध्यते भेदानिति वेदान्तनिश्चयः ॥ १२ ॥ ''Gaudapada Karika'' states that while we do grasp objects, we perceive, we think, but this does not connote the nature of reality and unreality, just like our fear of "a rope for a serpent in darkness".{{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=107}}For Sanskrit original and an alternate translation: RD Karmarkar (1953), [https://archive.org/stream/Gaudapada-Karika.English/Gaudapada-Karika#page/n71/mode/2up Gaudapada Karika], Bhandarkar Oriental Research Institute, Poona, page 13-14 with footnotes We construct realities, states Gaudapada, and imagine ''Jivatman'' to be various things such as ''prana'' (brreath), ''loka'' (world), ''deva'' (gods), ''bhoktr'' (enjoyer), ''bhojya'' (enjoyables), ''sukshma'' (subtle), ''sthula'' (gross), ''murta'' (material), ''amurta'' (nonmaterial) and so on.{{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=108}}For Sanskrit original and translation: RD Karmarkar (1953), [https://archive.org/stream/Gaudapada-Karika.English/Gaudapada-Karika#page/n73/mode/2up Gaudapada Karika], Bhandarkar Oriental Research Institute, Poona, pages 15-17 with footnotes, 77-84{{Sfn|Isaeva|1995|pp=44-45}} We imagine things in our mind, we create things in our mind, we destroy things in our mind, says Gaudapada; yet all these things are not different from It, the Atman (gender neutral).{{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=108}} All such constructions create dualities in our imagination, are [[Maya (illusion)|Maya]]. The true reality, state Karikas 33-36, is nondual and it is Atman.{{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=108}} Those who have mastered and grown past all attachments, past all fear and past all anger, they are past all dualities, know their Self, have secured the nonduality within. According to Karika 36-38, such wise individuals, do not care about praise from anyone, are beyond all rituals, are homeless wanderers, for they have realized the true inside them and outside; they, translates Potter, "remain steadfastly true to nature".{{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=108}}For Sanskrit original and translation: RD Karmarkar (1953), [https://archive.org/stream/Gaudapada-Karika.English/Gaudapada-Karika#page/n75/mode/2up Gaudapada Karika], Bhandarkar Oriental Research Institute, Poona, pages 18-19 with footnotes, 85-88 ====Chapter Three: Nonduality (Advaita)==== {{Quote box |quote = '''Duties of worship''' Duties of worship arise only for those who think something is born and who are thus miserable. I shall therefore speak of the nonmiserable state in which (...) |source = —''Gaudapada Karika 3.1–2''
Translator: Karl Potter{{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=108}}For Sanskrit original and an alternate translation: RD Karmarkar (1953), [https://archive.org/stream/Gaudapada-Karika.English/Gaudapada-Karika#page/n77/mode/2up Gaudapada Karika], Bhandarkar Oriental Research Institute, Poona, pages 19-20 with footnotes 1 & 2 for Third Chapter |bgcolor=#FFE0BB |align = right }} Gaudapada opens this chapter by criticizing devotional worship of any form, and states that this assumes that the Brahman-Atman is born.{{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=108}} He states that the nondual Brahman-Atman (Self) can give rise to apparent duality (''Jivas'', individual souls), while remaining unaffected in the process. To this end he gives the analogy of space and jars.{{Sfn|Potter|1981|pp=108-109}} Self is like space and the Jivas are like space in jars. Just as space is enclosed in a jar, so is the Self manifested as Jivas. When the jar is destroyed the space in the jar merges into space so likewise, are the Jivas one of the Self.{{Sfn|Potter|1981|pp=108-109}}For Sanskrit original and translation: RD Karmarkar (1953), [https://archive.org/stream/Gaudapada-Karika.English/Gaudapada-Karika#page/n77/mode/2up Gaudapada Karika], Bhandarkar Oriental Research Institute, Poona, pages 20-21 with footnotes Gaudapada states that the Upanishads such as the ''Brihadaranyaka Upanishad'' teach this, that one's own Atman (self) is identical to the Atman in other beings, and all Atman are identical with the Brahman.{{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=109}} While some Upanishads, acknowledges Gaudapada, imply a difference between individual soul and the Brahman, those texts are discussing the apparent distinction (duality) when one believes in apparent creation. In reality, states Gaudapada, there is no creation of souls from Brahman as they are identical.{{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=109}}For Sanskrit original and translation: RD Karmarkar (1953), [https://archive.org/stream/Gaudapada-Karika.English/Gaudapada-Karika#page/n79/mode/2up Gaudapada Karika], Bhandarkar Oriental Research Institute, Poona, pages 21-23 with footnotes We must not confuse passages meant for spiritual instruction. According to Karikas 3.17-18, Gaudapada admits that dualists disagree with this view, but the ancient texts admit duality in the context of appearances, while "nonduality is indeed the highest reality", translates Karmarkar.{{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=109}}For Sanskrit original and translation: RD Karmarkar (1953), [https://archive.org/stream/Gaudapada-Karika.English/Gaudapada-Karika#page/n81/mode/2up Gaudapada Karika], Bhandarkar Oriental Research Institute, Poona, pages 23-24 with footnotes 17 & 18 According to Karl Potter's translation of Karikas 3.33-36, an awareness that is without conceptual construction is unborn, and this is identical to the object of that awareness called [[Brahman]]. This awareness is not a metaphor, nor born, it is real. Such awareness shines forth without fear, beyond words and thought, is calm and unwavering, equanimous, and full of light.{{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=110}}For Sanskrit original and translation: RD Karmarkar (1953), [https://archive.org/stream/Gaudapada-Karika.English/Gaudapada-Karika#page/n85/mode/2up Gaudapada Karika], Bhandarkar Oriental Research Institute, Poona, pages 27-29 with footnotes This inner contactless concentration (Asparsha yoga) is difficult for most including the [[yogis]], who see fear in what is fearlessly blissful.{{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=110}}{{Refn|group=note|Adi Shankara interprets this Karika somewhat differently, according to Comans.{{Sfn|Michael Comans|2000|p=166}}}} Such is the awareness that comes from self-reflection, understanding, giving up attachment to ''Dukkha'' (frustration) and ''Sukha'' (pleasure), where the mind rests in indescribable calmness within.{{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=110}}For Sanskrit original and translation: RD Karmarkar (1953), [https://archive.org/stream/Gaudapada-Karika.English/Gaudapada-Karika#page/n85/mode/2up Gaudapada Karika], Bhandarkar Oriental Research Institute, Poona, pages 29-31 with footnotes{{Refn|group=note|दुःखं सर्वमनुस्मृत्य कामभोगान्निवर्तयेत् । अजं सर्वमनुस्मृत्य जातं नैव तु पश्यति ॥ ४३ ॥(...)
नाऽऽस्वादयेत्सुखं तत्र निःसङ्गः प्रज्ञया भवेत् । निश्चलं निश्चरच्चित्तमेकीकुर्यात्प्रयत्नतः ॥ ४५ ॥(...)
स्वस्थं शान्तं सनिर्वाणमकथ्यं सुखमुत्तमम् । अजमजेन ज्ञेयेन सर्वज्ञं परिचक्षते ॥ ४७ ॥}} ====Chapter Four: The Peace of The Firebrand (Alatasanti)==== The last chapter of ''Gaudapada Karika'' has a different style than the first three, and it opens by expressing reverence for all "the greatest of men", who are like the cosmic space through their awareness of nonduality, free from self-contradictions and confusion, and who understand [[Dharma]].{{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=110}} Karikas 3–10 repeat some content from previous chapters, but with some word substitutions.{{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=111}}For Sanskrit original and translation: RD Karmarkar (1953), [https://archive.org/stream/Gaudapada-Karika.English/Gaudapada-Karika#page/n89/mode/2up Gaudapada Karika], Bhandarkar Oriental Research Institute, Poona, pages 32-33 with footnotes Karikas 11–13 quote the key duality premise of [[Samkhya]] school of Hindu philosophy, cross examines it, then asks how and why is cause eternal? The text states that the Samkhya premise "cause is born as its effect" leads to infinite regress, which is not persuasive.{{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=111}} ''Gaudapada Karika'' then acknowledges the theory of [[Ajativada]] or non-origination of the ''Buddhas'' (Buddhists).{{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=111}} Like Samkhya premise, the text praises and cross examines it, in three ways: first, non-origination premises makes sense when neither the point of origin nor the end of something is known, but we know the point of origin of any example of something produced and there ''Ajativada'' premise does not follow; secondly, the ''Ajativada'' premise commits the ''Sadhyasama'' fallacy of reasoning by offering examples of what is yet to be proved.{{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=111}} Thirdly, state Karikas 29–41, neither [[samsara]] nor [[moksha|mukti]] has a beginning or end, because if something is born it must have an end, and something that is unborn has no end.{{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=112}}For Sanskrit original and translation: RD Karmarkar (1953), [https://archive.org/stream/Gaudapada-Karika.English/Gaudapada-Karika#page/n97/mode/2up Gaudapada Karika], Bhandarkar Oriental Research Institute, Poona, pages 39-41 with footnotes Karikas 45–52 state that only (''Vijnana'') consciousness is real, explaining it with an example of fire stick before and during the time it burns, and adding we construct and deconstruct our state of awareness.{{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=112}}For Sanskrit original and translation: RD Karmarkar (1953), [https://archive.org/stream/Gaudapada-Karika.English/Gaudapada-Karika#page/n101/mode/2up Gaudapada Karika], Bhandarkar Oriental Research Institute, Poona, pages 43-44 with footnotes Karikas 53–56 assert that there is no causation, no effects, and repeats that consciousness is the only one real thing.{{Sfn|Potter|1981|pp=112-113}} Everything is [[impermanence|impermanent]], nothing is eternal and everything is also without origination by nature, state Karikas 57–60.{{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=113}}For Sanskrit original and translation: RD Karmarkar (1953), [https://archive.org/stream/Gaudapada-Karika.English/Gaudapada-Karika#page/n103/mode/2up Gaudapada Karika], Bhandarkar Oriental Research Institute, Poona, pages 45-46 with footnotes Karikas 61–81 repeat text on four states from earlier chapters to re-emphasize the premises about impermanence and non-origination.{{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=113}}For Sanskrit original and translation: RD Karmarkar (1953), [https://archive.org/stream/Gaudapada-Karika.English/Gaudapada-Karika#page/n105/mode/2up Gaudapada Karika], Bhandarkar Oriental Research Institute, Poona, pages 47-52 with footnotes Attachment to unreality causes desire, sorrow (Dukkha) and fear, while detachment leads to freeing from such states and to ''samadhi''.{{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=113}} There are three stages of understanding state Karikas 87–89: ''Laukika'' (ordinary. which cognizes object and subject as real), ''Shuddha laukika'' (purified ordinary, perceiving is considered real but not the objects) and ''Lokottara'' (supramundane, where neither objects nor perceiving are cognized as real).{{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=113}}For Sanskrit original and translation: RD Karmarkar (1953), [https://archive.org/stream/Gaudapada-Karika.English/Gaudapada-Karika#page/n111/mode/2up Gaudapada Karika], Bhandarkar Oriental Research Institute, Poona, pages 53-54 with footnotes Karikas 90–100 presents ''Agrayana'' (vehicle) to knowing. The text states, "all dharmas are without beginning, without variety, and are consciousness only".{{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=113}} Duality is for the unwise, nonduality and undifferentiated Reality is for the wise and difficult to grasp. The last ''Karikas'' of the Chapter Four add, translates Karl Potter, "this the ''Buddhas'' understand, the Buddha instructs us that consciousness does not reach the dharmas, yet the Buddha said nothing about either consciousness or dharmas!"{{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=114}}For Sanskrit original and translation: RD Karmarkar (1953), [https://archive.org/stream/Gaudapada-Karika.English/Gaudapada-Karika#page/n113/mode/2up Gaudapada Karika], Bhandarkar Oriental Research Institute, Poona, pages 55-56 with footnotes ===Relationship to Buddhism=== The influence of Buddhist doctrines on Gaudapada has been a vexed question.{{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=105}}{{Sfn|Michael Comans|2000|p=2}} One school of scholars, such as Bhattacharya and Raju, state that Gaudapada took over the Buddhist doctrines that [[Yogacara#Representation-only|ultimate reality is pure consciousness (''vijñapti-mātra'')]]{{sfn|Raju|1971|p=177}}{{refn|group=note|It is often used interchangeably with the term ''citta-mātra'', but they have different meanings. The standard translation of both terms is "consciousness-only" or "mind-only." Several modern researchers object this translation, and the accompanying label of "absolute idealism" or "idealistic monism".{{sfn|Kochumuttom|1999|p=1}} A better translation for ''vijñapti-mātra'' is ''representation-only''.{{sfn|Kochumuttom|1999|p=5}}}} and "that the nature of the world is the four-cornered negation, which is the structure of Māyā".{{sfn|Raju|1971|p=177}}{{Sfn|Sarma|2007|pp=126, 143-144}}{{refn|group=note|1. Something is. 2. It is not. 3. It both is and is not. 4. It neither is nor is not.{{sfn|Garfield|Priest|2003}}{{page needed|date=August 2016}} The 'four-cornered negation' is an English gloss of the Sanskrit, [[Catuṣkoṭi|Chatushkoti]].{{citation needed|date=August 2016}}}} Gaudapada "wove [both doctrines] into the philosophy of ''Mandukaya Upanisad'', which was further developed by Shankara".{{sfn|Raju|1971|p=177-178}}{{refn|group=note|The influence of [[Mahayana Buddhism]] on other religions and philosophies was not limited to Vedanta. Kalupahana notes that the [[Visuddhimagga]] – a Theravada Buddhist tradition, contains "some metaphysical speculations, such as those of the Sarvastivadins, the Sautrantikas, and even the [[Yogacara|Yogacarins]]".{{sfn|Kalupahana|1994|p=206}}}} Of particular interest is Chapter Four, in which according to Bhattacharya, two karikas refer to the [[Gautama Buddha|Buddha]] and the term ''Asparsayoga'' is borrowed from Buddhism.{{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=105}} According to Murti, "the conclusion is irresistible that Gaudapada, a Vedanta philosopher, is attempting an advaitic interpretation of Vedanta in the light of the Madhyamika and Yogcara doctrines. He even freely quotes and appeals to them."TRV Murti (1955), The central philosophy of Buddhism, Routledge (2008 Reprint), {{ISBN|978-0-415-46118-4}}, pages 114-115 However, adds Murti, the doctrines are unlike Buddhism. Chapter One, Two and Three are entirely Vedantin and founded on the Upanishads, with little Buddhist flavor. While the first three chapters discuss [[Brahman]] and Atman (soul, Self), Chapter Four doesn't. This, according to Murti, may be because this was authored by someone else and not Gaudapada, a position shared by Richard King. Further, state both Murti and King, no Vedanta scholars who followed Gaudapada ever quoted from Chapter Four, they only quote from the first three. According to Sarma, Chapter Four may well have been written by Gaudapada assuming he was fully conversant with Mahayana school's teachings, yet "to mistake him to be a hidden or open Buddhist is absurd".{{Sfn|Sarma|2007|pp=145-147}} The doctrines of Gaudapada and Buddhism are totally opposed, states Murti: {{Quote| We have been talking of borrowing, influence and relationship in rather general terms. It is necessary to define the possible nature of the borrowing, granting that it did take place. (...) The Vedantins stake everything on the [[Atman (Hinduism)|Atman]] (Brahman) and accept the authority of the Upanishads. We have pointed out at length the [[Anatta|Nairatmya]] standpoint of Buddhism and its total opposition to the Atman (soul, substance, the permanent and universal) in any form. |TRV Murti|''The Central Philosophy of Buddhism''TRV Murti (1955), The central philosophy of Buddhism, Routledge (2008 Reprint), {{ISBN|978-0-415-46118-4}}, page 116}} Advaitins particularly have traditionally challenged the Buddhist influence thesis.{{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=105}} Modern scholarship generally accepts that Gaudapada was influenced by Buddhism, at least in terms of using Buddhist terminology to explain his ideas, but adds that Gaudapada was a Vedantin and not a Buddhist.{{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=105}} ==Other works by Gaudapadacharya== A number of additional works are attributed to Gaudapada, but their authenticity is uncertain.{{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=104}} The attributed works are:{{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=104}}{{sfn|Nakamura|2004|p=311}} * A [[bhasya]] on ''[[Brihadaranyaka Upanishad]]'' * A bhasya on ''[[Nrisimha Tapaniya Upanishad]]'' * A bhasya on [[Anugita]] * ''Durga Saptashati Tika'' — A bhasya on [[Devi Mahatmya]] * ''Sri Vidyaratna Sutra'' bhasya * ''Subhagodaya on Sri Vidya'' * ''Uttara Gita Bhashya'' Gaudapada is also credited with a commentary on ''Samkhyakarikas''. According to Potter, the naive nature of this commentary is in sharp contrast to the depth of reflection in ''Gaudapada Karikas'', and the commentary on ''Samkhyakarikas'' is unlikely to be one by Gaudapada.{{Sfn|Potter|1981|p=104}} ==Advaita guru-paramparā== {{Main|Advaita Guru Paramparā}} Gaudapada is one of the key persons in the Advaita Vedanta.{{Sfn|Michael Comans|2000|p=2}} He is traditionally said to have been highly influential on [[Adi Shankara]],{{sfn|Potter|1981|p=103}} one of the most important figures in Vedic philosophy. ==Shri Gaudapadacharya Math== {{Main|Shri Gaudapadacharya Math}} Shri Gaudapadacharya Math{{refn|group=note|{{lang-sa|श्री संस्थान गौडपदाचार्य मठ}}, {{IAST|Śrī Sansthāna Gauḍapadācārya Maṭha}}}}, also known as '''{{IAST|Kavaḷē maṭha}}''' {{lang|skt|कवळे मठ}}, is the oldest [[matha]] of the [[South India]]n [[Saraswat Brahmin]]s.{{cite book|title=Shri Gowdapadacharya & Shri Kavale Math (A Commemoration volume)| page=10}}http://www.shrikavalemath.org.in/ The [[Peetadhipathi]] "head monk" is Śrī Gauḍapadācārya. [[Rajapur Saraswat Brahmins]] and [[Smartism|Smartist]] [[Goud Saraswat Brahmin]]s are its main disciples.http://www.shrikavalemath.org.in/, Title: About Kavale matha. ==See also== '''List of Math''' *[[Kashi Math]] *[[Gokarna Math]] *[[Chitrapur Math]] *[[Dvaita]] *[[Madhwacharya]] ==Notes== {{reflist|group=note|2}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ===Published sources=== {{refbegin}} * {{cite book | last =Bhatta | first =Rathnakara | year =2013 | title =Shree Shankarayana (May. 2013), pp. 190–380. | url =http://www.goodreads.com/author_blog_posts/4295191-shree-shankarayana}} *{{cite book|ref=harv|author=Michael Comans|title=The Method of Early Advaita Vedānta: A Study of Gauḍapāda, Śaṅkara, Sureśvara, and Padmapāda|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sx12hxoFVqwC|year=2000|publisher=Motilal Banarsidass|isbn=978-81-208-1722-7}} * {{Citation | last1 =Garfield | first1 =Jay L. | last2 =Priest | first2 =Graham | year =2003 | title =Nagarjuna and the Limits of Thought, Philosophy East & West Volume 53, Number 1 January 2003 1–21 | url =http://www.thezensite.com/ZenEssays/Nagarjuna/NagarjunaTheLimitsOfThought.pdf}} * {{cite book|ref=harv|last=Isaeva|first=Natalia V. |title=From Early Vedanta to Kashmir Shaivism: Gaudapada, Bhartrhari, and Abhinavagupta|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hMCFQ39cHNkC |year=1995|publisher=State University of New York Press|isbn=978-0-7914-2449-0}} * {{Citation | last =Kalupahana | first =David J. | year =1994 | title =A History of Buddhist Philosophy | place =Delhi | publisher =Motilal Banarsidass Publishers Private Limited}} * {{Citation | last =Kochumuttom | first =Thomas A. | year =1999 | title =A Buddhist Doctrine of Experience. A New Translation and Interpretation of the Works of Vasubandhu the Yogacarin | place =Delhi | publisher =Motilal Banarsidass}} * {{Citation | last =Nakamura | first =Hajime | year =2004 | title =A History of Early Vedanta Philosophy. Part Two | place =Delhi | publisher =Motilal Banarsidass Publishers Private Limited}} *{{cite book |author=Gauḍapāda Ācārya |author2=Śaṅkarācārya |author3=Nikhilananda, Swami |author4= V Subrahmanya Iyer |year=1990 |title=Māṇḍūkyopaniṣad : with Gauḍapāda's Kārikā and Saṅkara's commentary |publisher=Advaita Ashrama |location=Calcutta |isbn=81-7505-022-5 |pages= }} * {{Citation | last =Potter | first =Karl. H. | year =1981 | title =''Gaudapada,'' Encyclopedia of Indian Philosophies: Advaita Vedānta up to Śaṃkara and his pupils, Volume 3, ''pp. 103-114'' | place =Delhi | publisher = Motilal Banarsidass | isbn =81-208-0310-8}} * {{Citation | last =Raju | first =P.T. | year =1971 | title =The Philosophical Traditions of India | place =Delhi | publisher =Motilal Banarsidass (1992 Reprint)}} * {{Citation | last =Sarma | first =Chandradhar | year =2007 |isbn= 978-8120813120 | title =The Advaita Tradition in Indian Philosophy | publisher =Motilal Banarsidass}} {{refend}} ==Further reading== * {{cite book | last =Dvivedi | first =Manilal N. | year =2003 | title =The Mandukyopanishad: With Gaudapada's Karikas and the Bhashya of Sankara | publisher =Jain Publishing Company}} * {{cite book|last=Fox|first=Douglas|title=Dispelling the Illusion|location=Albany|publisher=SUNY Press|year=1993}} * {{cite book|last=Jones|first=Richard H.|title=Gaudapada: Advaita Vedanta's First Philosopher|location=New York|publisher=Jackson Square Books|year=2014}} * {{cite book | last =King | first =Richard | year =1995 | title =Early Advaita Vedanta and Buddhism: The Mahayana Context of the Gaudapadiya-Karika | publisher =SUNY Press}} ==External links== * {{Internet Archive author}} * [https://www.wisdomlib.org/hinduism/book/mandukya-upanishad-karika-bhashya/index.html The Mandukya Upanishad/Karika, Shankara’s Commentary and Anandagiri’s Tika] Translated by Swami Nikhilananda, online ebook * [http://www.universaltheosophy.com/pdf-library/Mandukya%20Upanishad%20with%20Gaudapada-Karika_Johnston.pdf Gaudapada Karika], Translation and commentary by Charles Johnston, Theosophical Quarterly * [http://www.advaita-vedanta.org/avhp/gaudapada.html advaita-vedanta.org, ''Gaudapada''] * [http://www.swamij.com/upanishad-mandukya-karika.htm Mandukya Upanishad with Gaudapada's Karika] * [http://www.advaitayoga.org/advaitayogaarticles/karika.html P.J. Mazumdar, ''Gaudapada's Karika on the Mandukya Upanishad''] {{Hindudharma}} {{Indian Philosophy}} {{philosophy of religion}} {{Portalbar|Hinduism|Spirituality|Indian religions|India}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gaudapada}} [[Category:6th-century Indian philosophers]] [[Category:6th-century Indian monks]] [[Category:Ascetics]] [[Category:Advaitin philosophers]] [[Category:Ancient Indian philosophers]] [[Category:Ancient Indian writers]] [[Category:Consequentialists]] [[Category:Hindu philosophers]] [[Category:Hindu reformers]] [[Category:Hindu scholars]] [[Category:Idealists]] [[Category:Indian Hindu monks]] [[Category:Indian Hindu missionaries]] [[Category:Indian Hindu religious leaders]] [[Category:Indian yogis]] [[Category:Indian Hindu monks]] [[Category:Medieval Hindu religious leaders]] [[Category:Vedanta]] [[Category:Ontologists]] [[Category:Pantheists]] [[Category:Sanskrit writers]] [[Category:Indian male writers]] [[Category:6th-century Indian writers]]

revision.text:
[[File:Champagne de Vignerons sign.jpg|thumb|The ''Les Champagnes de Vignerons'' ("Vinegrower Champagnes") sign is displayed by many producers of Grower Champagne at their facilities. In this case Chartogne-Taillet in [[Merfy]].]] '''Grower Champagnes''' are those [[Champagne]]s that are produced by the same estate that owns the vineyards where the grapes are grown. ''Récoltant-Manipulant'' is the term in [[French language|French]], and Grower Champagnes can be identified by "RM" on the [[wine label]].<ref name="Stevenson pg 170-172">T. Stevenson, ed. ''The Sotheby's Wine Encyclopedia (4th Edition)'' pg 170-172 Dorling Kindersley 2005 {{ISBN|0-7513-3740-4}}</ref> While large [[Champagne house]]s, such as [[Mumm]], [[Moët et Chandon]], [[Veuve Clicquot]] and others may use grapes sourced from as many as 80 different vineyards in the [[Champagne region]] to create a consistent house style, Grower Champagnes tend to be more ''[[terroir]]''-focused, being sourced from a single vineyard or closely located vineyards around a village, and made with grapes which vary with each vintage.<ref name="Pitcher">S. Pitcher, [http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2004/12/16/WIG49ABV121.DTL&type=wine Grower-made Champagnes are an elegant alternative to big-house bubblies] ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'', December 16, 2004</ref> Today there are over 19,000 independent growers in the Champagne region,{{fact|date=January 2018}} accounting for nearly 88% of all vineyard land in the region; around 5,000 of these growers produce wine from their own grapes.{{fact|date=January 2018}} Of the Champagne imported into the US in 2014, only 5% was grower Champagne.<ref>[http://winefolly.com/review/grower-champagne-guide/ Getting into Grower Champagne] [[Wine Folly]], December 31, 2014</ref>
==Wine styles== Grower Champagnes have been described as "[[artisanal]] [[winemaking]]" with ''terroir'' being at the forefront for each wine,<ref name="Pitcher"/><ref name="NYTimes">A. Cortese, [https://www.nytimes.com/2007/12/23/business/yourmoney/23bubbly.html?_r=1&em&ex=1198645200&en=53e3b0b2a49502b8&ei=5087%0A Champagne Beyond the Big Names] ''[[New York Times]]'', December 23, 2007</ref> rather than an emphasis on a consistent "house style" that can be made year after year.<ref name="Gregutt">P. Gregutt ''"[http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/pacificnw/2004082996_pacificptaste23.html Bottling Their Own]"'' Seattle Times, December 23rd 2007</ref> While large [[Champagne houses]], such as [[Moët et Chandon]] may source grapes from the entire [[Champagne region]], the vineyards owned by a Grower Champagne maker are generally clustered around a single village. Some growers will craft their wine to reflect the ''terroir'' of that village, especially if they own vineyards in one of [[Champagne's Grand crus]]. Grower Champagnes are often released younger than their large house counterparts due, in part, to the greater financial resources that would be needed for long term [[aging (wine)|aging]] and storage.<ref name="Pitcher"/> Many also show a lower [[dosage (wine)|dosage]], and occasionally no dosage at all, than most negociant manipulant bottlings.
==RM Champagne producers== Producers of RM Champagne include [[Tarlant]], [[Chartogne-Taillet]], [[David Léclapart]], [[Benoît Lahaye]], [[Roses de Jeanne]], [[Marie-Courtin]], [[Vilmart & Cie]], [[Pierre Péters]], [[Agrapart & Fils]], and [[Marc Hébrart]].<ref name="10 top">[http://www.decanter.com/wine-reviews-tastings/10-top-grower-champagnes-to-try-270410/ 10 top grower Champagnes to try: Champagne resident and expert Peter Liem picks out 10 top grower Champagnes to try] [[decanter.com]] August 13, 2015</ref>
==Recent vintages== The 2011 vintage saw difficult conditions which created uneven wines.<ref name="10 top" /> The 2009 vintage was warm enough to ripen the fruit, resulting full, fruity Champagnes.<ref name="10 top" /> 2008 was an outstanding vintage, showing both high ripeness and high acidity.<ref name="10 top" />
==Sales market== [[File:Champagne Blanc de Blancs 1er Cru Naveau.jpg|thumb|Champagne Blanc de Blancs 1er Cru Naveau]] The popularity of Grower Champagne is a relatively recent phenomenon.<ref name="Bonne">J. Bonne ''"[http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2008/12/11/WI9B14K51T.DTL The Chronicle Wine Selections: Grower Champagne]"'' San Francisco Chronicle, December 12, 2008</ref> Since the 18th century, Champagne houses have dominated the business dynamic in the region. These private houses or ''[[negociant]]s'' would buy grapes from the owners of several vineyards to blend and make Champagne.<ref name="Johnson pg 330-341">H. Johnson ''Vintage: The Story of Wine'' pg 330-341 Simon and Schuster 1989 {{ISBN|0-671-68702-6}}</ref> As of 2003, there were over 3,700 brands of Grower Champagnes available for purchase within [[France]] but only around 130 brands in the [[United States]].<ref name="Pitcher"/> As of 2008, these wines accounted for less than 3% of Champagne market, with that market growing as the wines continue to increase in popularity.<ref name="Bonne"/> Distributors and wine retailers tend to tout the comparative value and lower cost of Grower Champagnes versus the wines of larger Champagne houses, due to the larger Champagne houses' costs of mass market advertising.<ref name="NYTimes"/> The smaller Growers leave it up to the importer and wine retailer to market their wines.<ref name="Pitcher"/>
==Criticism== A common criticism of Grower Champagnes is the potential for variable quality,<ref name="Bonne"/> especially from [[vintage]] to vintage. While the larger Champagne houses and ''negociants'' have the flexibility to buy grapes from all over the Champagne region, Grower Champagne makers are limited to only their vineyard holdings. Conversely, advocates of Grower Champagnes say that the blending of many ''[[terroir]]s'' by the larger houses makes those wines "underflavored" and non-distinctive.<ref name="Gregutt"/>
==Vineyard lands== There are over 19,000 independent growers in the Champagne region, accounting for nearly 88% of all vineyard land in the region. Around 5000 of these growers produce wine from their own grapes. The larger Champagne houses have holdings in only 12% of the region's vineyards, making it a necessity for them to buy grapes from independent growers.<ref name="Stevenson pg 170-172"/> Under current ''[[Appellation d'origine contrôlée]]'' (AOC) regulations, there are strict limitations on planting. Some growers are seeing an economic advantage in making wine from their own grapes, especially if they have land in one of Champagne's Grand cru villages, rather than selling them to the larger houses where they become part of a generic blend.<ref name="Gregutt"/>
==Identifying Champagnes== [[File:Blanc de blanc grand Cru champagne.jpg|right|thumb|A Grand Cru grower Champagne with the "RM" visible on the lower right corner.]] Champagnes can be identified by the initials that appear before a number on the wine label. The initials most commonly associated with Grower Champagnes is '''RM''' (meaning ''Récoltant-Manipulant'') but there are other initials that may appear on the label.
Other initials:<ref name="Stevenson pg 170-172"/> *The initials '''NM''' (meaning ''Négociant-Manipulant'') appear on the labels of large Champagne houses that source the majority of their grapes rather than growing them.<ref name="Stevenson pg 170-172"/> *'''CM''' (meaning ''Coopérative-Manipulant'') is a [[co-operative]] of growers who blend the product of their collective vineyards to sell under one or more brands. In this situation the individual grower may have some involvement in the winemaking process. *'''RC''' (meaning ''Récoltant-Coopérateur'') is a wine sourced from a single grower but made entirely for him by a co-operative winemaking facility. While the wine is sold under the grower's own brand, he will often have had very little if any involvement in the winemaking process. *'''SR''' (meaning ''Société de Récoltants'') is a registered firm set up by two or more growers who share the same winery which they use to make wine to sell under their own label. This designation differs from a CM in that the growers almost always have significant involvement in the winemaking process.
==References== {{reflist}}
{{wines}}
[[Category:Wine terminology]] [[Category:Champagne (wine)]]

revision.text:
'''Interpreting notes''' are used by some [[Language interpretation|interpreters]], who re-express oral communications (such as [[Public speaking|speeches]]) in whole or in part. Such notes may be used when the interpreter is working in "[[Language interpretation#Consecutive|consecutive mode]]." Interpreting notes are not part of any conventional graphic system, and practitioners are free to develop their own techniques. However, some basic rules facilitate the recording of details in order to aid the interpreter in coping with large amounts of information. ==Theory== The purpose of interpreting notes is not to [[wikt:transcribe|transcribe]] the [[Public speaking|speech]] verbatim. Interpreting notes are not a form of [[shorthand]]. Their purpose is to write minimal notes which will, at a quick glance, elicit in the interpreter's mind the intent of an oral communication so that it can be re-expressed in a different language. It is not appropriate to document a speech in [[shorthand]], as this would result in task duplication. ==Practice== [[Image:Interpreting notes.JPG|thumb|250px|Typical interpreting notes.]] The interpreter should listen with utmost concentration to the speaker and write only the information which he judges sufficient to render the meaning. Numbers, names, and the [[title]]s of persons must be retained in the interpretation. Interpreting notes are typically written in a [[notebook]] with each note being separated from the others by a horizontal line. After interpreting a sentence with the aid of a note, some interpreters might make a [[Slash (punctuation)|slash]] over it, if they have the time. This has an important psychological effect — it is similar to erasing data on a computer. Others might consider it too time-consuming to do so when a fast pace of interpretation is required or they might think that it detracts from the pace of their delivery. The interpreter is required to decipher his notes and to re-express their content in the target language. Following analysis of the speech, the interpreter may write the information in [[Abstract (summary)|abstract form]]. ===Ideograms=== [[Ideogram]]s are an important tool used by interpreters. For example, the letter “E” laid on its side (like the [[Cyrillic script|Cyrillic]] letter [[Sha (Cyrillic)|''sha'', Ш]]) may represent Europe. Then one can specify whether eastern, western, or central Europe is meant by slashing the relevant upward leg. A horizontal bar with two vertical bars beneath it might represent a table, which would indicate a meeting or a conference. A bracket before an action indicates that the action will take place in the future, and vice versa. These ideograms are linked by a system of arrows and brackets that show the structure of a sentence that is to be interpreted. Using this system, one can note, for instance, that a sum has increased or decreased by a certain percentage (according to the arrow’s direction). For example, the notes in the illustration might be interpreted to mean :
We are particularly glad to inform you about an important increase in our company’s revenues, which rose by 10 percent from 3.5 to 3.85 billion dollars.(*) This derives from huge sales of helicopters. The United States of America bought 50 and South Africa 20 of them. On the other hand, we must relocate parts of our production in these countries.   (A [[1000000000 (number)|billion]] (bn) is called a milliard (mrd or Md) in most languages.)*
Some interpreters have devised complete systems of abbreviations, which include all academic titles, administrative titles, military ranks, etc. Such a system has the drawback that, like shorthand, it may be useful only for a particular language. ==Bibliography== * Andres, Dorte: ''Konsekutivdolmetschen und Notation.'' 2000, {{ISBN|3-631-39856-5}} *Farwick, Judith: ''Between the Signs. How to take notes without words''. 2018. {{ISBN|9783752802696}} * {{Cite book|title=Note-taking for Consecutive Interpreting: A Short Course|last=Gillies|first=Andrew|publisher=Routledge|year=2017|isbn=1317302680|edition=2nd|location=|pages=|author-link=Andrew Gillies}} ** Gillies, Andrew (2005). ''Note-taking for Consecutive Interpreting''. {{ISBN|1-900650-82-7}}. * Jones, Roderick: ''Conference Interpreting Explained.'' 1998, {{ISBN|1-900650-57-6}} * Matyssek, Heinz: ''Handbuch der Notizentechnik für Dolmetscher. Ein Weg zur sprachunabhängigen Notation.'' 1989, {{ISBN|3-87276-616-3}} * Rozan, Jean-François: ''La Prise de Notes en Interprétation Consécutive.'' 1956, {{ISBN|2-8257-0053-3}} * [[Danica Seleskovitch|Seleskovitch, Danica]]: ''Langage, langues et mémoires.''1975, {{ISBN|2-256-90752-X}} * [[Mary Snell-Hornby|Snell-Hornby, Mary]]/Hönig, Hans G./Kußmaul, Paul/Schmitt, Peter A.: ''Handbuch Translation.'' 1999, {{ISBN|3-86057-995-9}} ==External links== * [http://interpreters.free.fr/consecnotes/notes.htm Note-taking for Consecutive Interpreting (Interpreter Training Resources)] [[Category:Language interpretation]] [[Category:Communication]]

'''Ives Roqueta''' ({{IPA-oc|ˈives ruˈketɔ}}; born 29 February 1936 in [[Sète]], [[Hérault]], died January 4, 2015) was an [[Occitan]] author. He played a major role in the country's political and cultural movement. He was the president of the [[Institut d'Estudis Occitans|IEO]] for a number of years and his brother Joan, better known as [[Joan Larzac]], is a writer and an Occitan activist as well. He founded the Ventadorn record company, which can be credited for providing [[Nòva cançon]] singers with a proficient media outlet.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.jornalet.com/nova/4542/es-mort-ives-roqueta|title=Es mòrt Ives Roqueta|publisher=jornalet.com|date=6 January 2015|language=French}}</ref>
==Controversy== His cultural and political action is highly controversial.
Some think that he's one of the pioneers of his generation and stands among the nation's most talented poets and novelists.
Other Occitan analysts say that he had a very negative impact over the occitanist movement during the end of the 1970s and the 1980s. Particularly, his anti-scholar positions led to the split of the [[Institut d'Estudis Occitans|IEO]] in 1981.<ref>[[Robèrt Lafont|LAFONT Robèrt]] (1979) ''Nani Monsur'', Valdériès: Vent Terral.</ref><ref>[[Robèrt Lafont|LAFONT Robèrt]] (1991) ''Temps tres'', coll. Internacional, Perpignan: Trabucaire.</ref><ref>[[Felip Martèl|MARTÈL Felip]] (1989b) = MARTEL Philippe, “Un peu d’histoire: bref historique de la revendication occitane, 1978-1988”, ''Amiras'' 20 (''Mort et résurrection de Monsieur Occitanisme''): 11-23</ref>
==Bibliography== ===Poems=== * ''L'Escriveire public'' (''The Letter-Writer''), 1958 * ''Lo Mal de la tèrra'' (''The Land's Evil''), 1958 * ''Roèrgue, si'' (''Yes to [[Rouergue]]''), 1968 * ''Òda a Sant Afrodisi'' (''An Ode to Saint [[Aphrodite]]''), 1968 * ''Lo Castèl des cans'' (''The Castle of the Dogs''), 1977 * ''Messa pels pòrcs'' (''A Mass for the Pigs''), 1970 * ''Los Negres, siam pas sols'' (''Blacks, Let's Not Be Alone''), 1972 * ''Lo Fuòc es al cementiri'' (''The Cemetery's on Fire''), 1974 * ''Misericòrdia'' (''Mercy''), 1986 * ''L'Escritura publica o pas'' (''Letter-Writing or Not''), 1988, a collection of poems written between 1972 and 1987
===Prose=== * ''Lo Poèta es una vaca'' (''The Poet Is a Cow''), 1967 * ''La Paciéncia'' (''Patience''), 1968 * ''Made in France'' (1970) * ''Lo Trabalh de las mans'' (''Handmade''), 1977 * ''Lengadòc Roge'' (''Red [[Languedoc]]''), 1984
===Essays=== * ''Los Carbonièrs de La Sala'' (''[[Decazeville]]'s Miners''), 1975 * ''Las Cronicas de Viure'' (''The Chronicles in ''Viure'' magazine''), 1963–1974
==Discography== * ''Messa Pels Porcs" ("Mass For Pigs"), Institut D'estudis Occitans/Ventadorn I.E.O. S-4 332, 1971
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://poemsintranslation.blogspot.com/2009/11/yves-rouquette-every-language-from.html English translation of ''Tota Lenga'']
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Roqueta, Ives}} [[Category:1936 births]] [[Category:2015 deaths]] [[Category:People from Sète]] [[Category:Occitan-language writers]]

revision.comment: Robot - Speedily moving category Academic pressure in East Asian cultures to [[:Category:Academic pressure in East Asian culture]] per [[WP:CFDS|CFDS]].
revision.text:
'''Jaesusaeng''' ({{Korean|hangul=재수생|hanja={{linktext|再|修|生}}|lit="restudy student"}}) is a [[Korean language|Korean]] term for [[high school]] students who decide to spend a year studying to re-take the [[College Scholastic Ability Test]], hoping to get a higher score and enter the university of their choice.<ref>{{cite news | last= [[Lee (Korean name)|Lee]] | first= Seokyong | url= http://web.archive.org/web/20080704001419/http://www.iht.com/slideshows/2008/06/25/asia/26cram-slideshow.php | title= Students on a mission | publisher= [[International Herald Tribune]] }}</ref> Attending university has a major impact on their future careers.<ref>{{cite news | last= Choe | first= Sang-Hun | url= http://web.archive.org/web/20080627155431/http://www.iht.com/articles/2008/06/25/asia/cram.php | title= At South Korean cram school, a singular focus | publisher= [[International Herald Tribune]] | date= June 25, 2008 }}</ref> The equivalent term in [[Education in Japan|Japan]] is ''[[Rōnin (student)|rōnin]]''.
== Social context == Gaining entrance to the extremely competitive and prestigious [[SKY (universities)|SKY universities]] in [[Seoul]] requires that some students become ''jaesusaeng'' after an initial less-than-stellar performance on the [[College Scholastic Ability Test|national exam]]. Korea is "prepossessed by social status and reputation," and a SKY education is the main way to gain [[social status]].<ref name="koreatimes Goh-Grapes">{{cite news | last= Goh-Grapes | first= Agnes | url= http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2009/02/117_40060.html | title= Phenomenon of Wild Goose Fathers in South Korea | publisher= [[Korea Times]] | date= 2009-02-22 | accessdate= 28 July 2010}}</ref>
Generally, the public education system is not enough to prepare students for the exam, so most students attend after school lessons at various ''[[hagwon]]'' ([[cram school]]s). The fierce competition for enrollment at prestigious universities is called "entrance exam war" ({{korean|labels=no|hangul=입시전쟁|hanja={{linktext|入|試|戰|爭}}|rr=ipsi jeonjaeng}}).
==Effects== The [[stress (biological)|stress]] from constant study and limited [[Interpersonal relationship|social life]] as a student have contributed to an increase in [[suicide in South Korea]]; for children aged 10 to 19 years old, suicide is the second most common cause of death in the country.<ref name="koreatimes Goh-Grapes" />
==Related term== When a student fails to earn an adequate score over 3 or more years, he may be derisively referred to as a ''jangsusaeng'' ({{korean|labels=no|hangul=장수생|hanja={{linktext|長|壽|生}}|lit=literally "long life student"}}) a [[Pun|play on words]] from the expression "Please live a long life" said to elders (장수 하세요). However, since 2010, the word "N susaeng" ({{korean|labels=no|hangul=엔수생|hanja=N壽生}}) is in common use. Although the definition of the word and the use of it is identical to the formerly used vocabulary, the Chinese character ''jang'' (長, meaning "long") is replaced with the Latin letter 'N', which stands for the undefined number of time the student is taking the test.
==See also== *[[Buke (China)|Buke]] *[[Rōnin (student)]] *[[Hagwon]] *[[Education in South Korea]] *[[Cram school]] *[[Deksil]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Academic pressure in East Asian culture]] [[Category:Education in South Korea]] [[Category:Korean words and phrases]] [[Category:Neologisms]] [[Category:Students in South Korea]] [[Category:South Korean culture]]
{{korea-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Spanish name|Camacho|Cordón}} [[File:2007-11-24 camacho.JPG|thumb|Jorge Camacho in 2007]] '''Jorge Camacho Cordón''' (born 18 November 1966, [[Zafra]]) is a writer in [[Esperanto]] and [[Spanish language|Spanish]].
Camacho was born in [[Zafra]], [[Spain]] and learned Esperanto in 1980. He was a member of the Academy of Esperanto from 1992 until 2001. Since 1995 he has worked in [[Brussels]] as an interpreter for the [[European Union]] from [[English language|English]] and [[Finnish language|Finnish]] into Spanish.
Camacho was elected to the [[Academy of Esperanto]] in 1992, but on 15 August 2001 he announced his resignation due to disappointment with the Esperanto movement. However, he remains active in Esperanto and continues to review literary works.
== Works == Camacho became famous for his poems and short stories in the late 1980s, for which he received several prizes in the ''Belartaj Konkursoj de UEA''. In 1992 he won the [[Grabowski Prize]], a prize for young authors writing in Esperanto. The prize is named after [[Antoni Grabowski]].
Camacho was in the early 1990s considered a member of the so-called ''Ibera Skolo'' ("Iberian School") of Esperanto writers along with three other inhabitants of the [[Iberian peninsula]].
In the 1990s, Camacho began to publicly oppose [[Giorgio Silfer]] for his interpretation of the political view "[[Raumism]]". He wrote ''La Majstro kaj Martinelli'' ("The Master and Martinelli"), a biting satire of Silfer (inspired by [[The Master and Margarita|the similarly titled novel]] of [[Mikhail Bulgakov]]), and criticised his ideology in ''La liturgio de la foiro'' ("The Liturgy of the Fair").
=== Poetry === * ''Ibere libere'' (with [[Miguel Fernández (poet)|Miguel Fernández]], [[Gonçalo Neves]] and [[Liven Dek]], pseudonym of Miguel Gutiérrez, 1993) * ''Celakantoj'' (''Coelacanths''; poems written in Esperanto c. 1989-1995, 2004) * ''Saturno'' (''Saturn''; bilingual collection of poems written both in Spanish and Esperanto c. 1995-2004, 2004) * ''Eklipsas'' (''[It] eclipses''; collection of poems written mainly in Esperanto 2004-2006, with translations into Spanish, 2007) * ''Koploj kaj filandroj'' (poems written in Esperanto, 2009)
== Editorial work == Until December 2014 Jorge Camacho was editor-in-chief of the literary almanac ''[[Beletra Almanako]]'', which was first issued in the autumn of 2007.
==External links== {{Sister project links|wikt=no|b=no|q=no|s=no|commons=Category:Jorge Camacho|n=no|v=no|species=no|d=Q12862|voy=no|m=no|mw=no}} * [http://jorgesaturno.blogspot.com/ Jorge Camacho blog] in Spanish * [http://jorgecice.blogspot.com/ Jorge Camacho blog] in Esperanto * {{Gutenberg author | id=Camacho,+Jorge | name=Jorge Camacho}} * {{Internet Archive author |sname=Jorge Camacho}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Camacho, Jorge}} [[Category:1966 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Zafra]] [[Category:Writers of Esperanto literature]] [[Category:Spanish male writers]] [[Category:Extremaduran writers]] [[Category:Spanish Esperantists]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=September 2018}} {{Infobox writer | name = K. T. Muhammed | image = Bust_of_KT_Mohammed.jpg | caption = Bust of K. T. Mohammed located in Calicut | birth_date = {{birth date|1927|09|29|df=yes}} | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|2008|03|25|1927|09|29}} | occupation = [[Playwright]] | spouse = {{marriage|[[Zeenath]]|1981|1993|reason=div}} | nationality = Indian }}
'''K. T. Muhammed''' (29 September 1927 – 25 March 2008), popularly known as '''KT''', was a [[Malayalam]] [[playwright]] and [[screenwriter]].<ref name="hindu_mar08">{{cite news|publisher = [[The Hindu]] |title = K.T. Mohammed passes away |url = http://www.hindu.com/2008/03/26/stories/2008032655581000.htm|date = 26 March 2008|accessdate = 30 June 2009}}</ref> He had scripted about 40 stage plays, including ''Idhu Bhumiyanu'' (This is the Earth), considered to be his masterpiece. He had also written screenplay for about 20 films, including ''[[Kandam Becha Kottu]]'', ''Thurakkatha Vathil'', ''[[Moodupadam]]'', and ''[[Kadalpalam]]''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hindu.com/thehindu/holnus/009200803270322.htm|title=Tearful farewell to Kerala's master playwright |date=27 March 2008 |publisher=[[The Hindu]]|accessdate=9 May 2010}}</ref> KT was a recipient of [[Sangeet Natak Akademi Award]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sangeetnatak.com/programmes_recognition&honours_drama_playwriting.html |title=Akademi Awards - Drama |publisher=Sangeet Natak Akademi |accessdate=2009-06-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081005121256/http://www.sangeetnatak.com/programmes_recognition%26honours_drama_playwriting.html |archivedate=5 October 2008 |df= }}</ref>
==Early life==
K.T. was born in [[Manjeri]] in [[Malappuram district]] as the eldest son of a policeman and had very little formal education. After schooling he worked as a clerk in the postal department. In 1952 he got the first prize in an all India short story contest for his story ''Kannukal'' (Eyes) which was later translated into many foreign languages. He was an active member of Brothers Music Club of [[Kozhikode]] which was the training ground of many famous artists.<ref name="hindu_mar08" /> He worked as the editor of Chithrakarthika weekly for a brief period of time. He started ''Sangamam Theatre'' a professional drama troup which staged many of his famous plays both inside and outside the state. In 1971, he was nominated as the Chairman of [[Kerala Sangeetha Nadaka Academy, Thrissur|Kerala Sangeetha Nadaka Academy]] and in 1974 as Chairman of Kerala State Film Development Corporation.<ref>Akhilavijnanakosam (An Encyclopaedia in [[Malayalam]]), [[D. C. Books]], [[Kottayam]].</ref> He married to actress [[Zeenath]] and that relation ended in divorce. They couple has a son Jithin.
He died on 25 March 2008 at [[Pavangad, Kozhikode]].<ref name="hindu_mar08" />
==Literary career==
His plays celebrate the values of basic human dignity which transcend the barriers of religion or community.<ref>{{cite book | first=G. Sankara | last=Pillai | title=Malayala Nadaka Sahithya Charithram|year=2008|publisher=[[Kerala Sangeetha Nadaka Academy, Thrissur]] |isbn=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hindu.com/2006/07/24/stories/2006072400640200.htm|title=Writer and reformer |date=24 July 2006|publisher=The Hindu|accessdate=9 May 2010}}</ref>
===Selected Plays===
*''Oorum Perum'' (A Person with Name and Dignity) *''Avar Theerumanikkunnu'' (They are Deciding) *''Karavatta Pashu'' (The Cow that Stopped Milking) *''Manushyan Karagruhathil'' (Man in Prison) *''Ithu Bhoomiyanu'' (This is the Earth) *''Kaffar'' *''Acchanum Bappayum'' *''Naalkkavala'' (The Junction) *''Njan Pedikkunnu'' (I am Getting Frightened) *''Kainathikal'' *''Pendulam'' *''Kalithokku'' (The Toy Gun) *''Operation Theatre'' *''Srishti'' (The Creation) *''Sthithi'' *''Samharam'' (The Annihilation) *''Sakshatkaram'' (The Fulfillment) *''Samanwayam'' (The Union) *''Sanatanum'' (The Eternal) *''Sannaham'' *''Vellapokkam'' (The Flood) *''Deepasthambam Mahashcharyam'' *" Soothradharan"
==Awards== *[[Kerala State Film Award]]s twice, for the Best [[Screenwriting]]; ''Kumarasambavam'', 1969 and ''Achanum Bappayum'', 1972 *[[Sangeet Natak Akademi Award]], 1986 * Bahrain Keraleeya Samajam "Sahithya Award", 2005
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.calicutcity.com/persons/ktmuhammed.htm K. T. at Calicutcity.com]
{{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Muhammed, K. T.}} [[Category:Indian Muslims]] [[Category:Screenwriters from Kerala]] [[Category:Malayali people]] [[Category:Malayalam-language writers]] [[Category:Malayalam-language dramatists and playwrights]] [[Category:1927 births]] [[Category:2008 deaths]] [[Category:People from Malappuram district]] [[Category:Kerala State Film Award winners]] [[Category:Malayalam screenwriters]] [[Category:Indian male dramatists and playwrights]] [[Category:20th-century Indian dramatists and playwrights]] [[Category:Manjeri]] [[Category:20th-century Indian male writers]]

'''L-Shares''' ({{zh|c=L股}}) refers to Chinese companies [[listed company|listed]] on the [[London Stock Exchange]]. The listed companies are incorporated in the [[Cayman Islands]], [[Bermuda]], [[British Virgin Islands]] and Jersey, but they have their main business operations in [[mainland China]]. <ref>{{cite book |title=Chinese stock markets: a research handbook |last=Su |first=Dongwei |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=2003 |publisher=World Scientific |location= |isbn=978-981-02-4512-2 |page=9 |pages= |url= |accessdate=}}</ref> They are listed on the London Stock Exchange according to a memorandum of understanding signed between the [[UK]] and [[China]]'s relevant authorities on October 7, 1996.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eastlaw.net/research/securities/sec2d.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-10-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090116043644/http://www.eastlaw.net/research/securities/sec2d.htm |archivedate=2009-01-16 |df= }}</ref>
==See also== *[[Chip (stock market)|Chip]] * [[A share (mainland China)|A share]] * [[B share (mainland China)|B share]] * [[H share]] * [[Red chip]] * [[P chip]] * [[S chip]] * [[N share]] * L share * [[G share]] * [[China Concepts Stock]]

There are 109 languages listed

revision.comment: Reverting possible vandalism by [[Special:Contribs/2601:600:A080:2791:75F6:3C88:6D78:D96|2601:600:A080:2791:75F6:3C88:6D78:D96]] to version by 63.173.123.163. [[WP:CBFP|Report False Positive?]] Thanks, [[WP:CBNG|ClueBot NG]]. (3287046) (Bot)
revision.text:
This is a '''list of common political [[metaphor]]s.'''
==Relating to the executive== * [[eminence grise]]: literally, "grey man," from French. Colloquially, the power-behind-the-throne. An official close to the president or monarch who has so much power behind the scenes that he or she may double or serve as the monarch. * [[figurehead]]: a leader whose powers are entirely symbolic, such as a [[constitutional monarch]]. * [[puppet government]]: a government that is manipulated by a foreign power for its own interests. * [[star chamber]]: a secretive council or other group within a government that possesses the actual power, regardless of the government's overt form.
==Relating to legislation== * [[blank check]] legislation which is vaguely worded to the point where it can be widely exploited and abused. * [[grandfather clause]] that allows a piece of legislation not to apply to something old or incumbent. * [[poison pill]] a provision in an act or bill which defeats or undermines its initial purpose or makes it politically unacceptable. * [[pork barrel]] legislation or patronage: acts of government that blatantly favor powerful [[Lobby groups|special interest group]]s. * [[rider (legislation)|rider]] that attaches something new or unrelated to an existing bill. * [[sunset clause]] to prevent legislation from being permanent. *a [[trigger law]] that will automatically "spring" into effect once some other variable occurs.
==Relating to elections== * [[character assassination]]: spreading (usually) manufactured stories about a candidate with the intent to destroy his or her reputation in the eyes of the public. * [[Dark horse|dark/black horse]]: a candidate who is largely ignored by opponents yet makes significant gains. * [[gerrymandering]]: reshaping district lines to include/exclude segments of voters that may help/hurt your chances of election. * [[landslide victory]]: a huge victory for one side. * [[muckraking]]: uncovering and publicizing scandalous information about a person or organization * [[mudslinging]]: harsh partisan insults exchanged between candidates. * [[parachute candidate]] / [[carpetbagger]]: a candidate who runs for election in an area which he or she is not a native resident or has no ties. * [[paper candidate]]: a candidate who puts no effort into his campaign and is essentially just a name on the ballot. * [[Coattail effect|riding coattails]]: victories by local or state politicians because of the popularity of more powerful politicians. * [[sacrificial lamb]]: a candidate who is put forward to run for office, by his party or others, but who has no chance of winning. * [[stalking horse]]: a perceived front-runner candidate who unifies his or her opponents, usually within a single political party. * [[grassroots]]: a political movement driven by the constituents of a community. * [[astroturfing]]: formal public relations campaigns in politics and advertising that seek to create the impression of being spontaneous, grassroots behavior. * [[wikt:stooge|stooge]]: To mislead a candidate or campaigner, or to masquerade as a constituent interested in an issue being promoted.
==Relating to world politics== *[[hard power]]: using military force against another country as form of punishment. *[[soft power]]: using economic and diplomatic sanctions against another country as a form of punishment. *[[soft tyranny]]: when a democratic government uses its power in a manner which diminishes the rights or power of the voters. *[[big stick diplomacy]]: flexing muscles militarily against other countries to show dominance.
==Relating to the issues== * [[wedge issue]]: an issue which turns members of a party against each other. * [[third rail (metaphor)|third rail]]: an issue which is so controversial, pursuing it or even attempting to address it could end one's political career. * [[straw man]]: the practice of refuting an argument that is weaker than one's opponent actually offers, or which he simply has not put forth at all. A type of logical fallacy. * [[sacred cow (idiom)|sacred cow]]: an institution which few dare question, because it is so revered.
==Others== * [[bread and circuses]]: satisfaction of shallow or immediate desires of the populace at the expense of good policy; also, the erosion of civic duty and the public life in a populace. * [[Government in the sunshine]]: a government which keeps all its records and documents open and easily accessible by the public. * [[lame duck (politics)|lame duck]]: a politician who has lost an election, or who is serving his last term in an office where the law limits the number of times he may succeed himself, and is simply waiting for his term to expire. * [[melting pot]]: a society in which all outsiders assimilate to one social norm. * [[Salad bowl (cultural idea)|salad bowl]]: a society in which cultural groups retain their unique attributes (opposite of melting pot theory). * [[Spin (public relations)]]: a heavily biased portrayal of an event or situation. * [[Turkeys voting for Christmas]]: Acting against one's own interests with no conceivable gain. * [[witch-hunt]]: a hysterical pursuit of political enemies.
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:List Of Political Metaphors}} [[Category:Political terminology]] [[Category:Political metaphors| ]]
